title: Enacts the "safe patient handling act"
summary: Creates the New York state safe patient handling task force.
fulltext:
S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         1370

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

                                      (PREFILED)

                                    January 5, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by M. of A. LANCMAN -- read once and referred to the Commit-
         tee on Health

       AN ACT to amend the public health law and the education law, in relation
         to a safe patient handling policy for health care facilities

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  This  act  shall  be  known and may be cited as the "safe
    2  patient handling act".
    3    S 2. Article 29-D of the public health law is amended by adding a  new
    4  title 4 to read as follows:
    5                                   TITLE 4
    6                        SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY
    7  SECTION 2999-G. LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
    8          2999-H. DEFINITIONS.
    9          2999-I. NEW YORK STATE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING TASK FORCE.
   10          2999-J. STATEWIDE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY.
   11          2999-K. HEALTH CARE FACILITY SAFE PATIENT HANDLING COMMITTEES.
   12          2999-L. ENFORCEMENT.
   13    S  2999-G.  LEGISLATIVE  INTENT.  THE  LEGISLATURE  HEREBY  FINDS  AND
   14  DECLARES THAT IT IS IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST TO  ENACT  A  STATEWIDE  SAFE
   15  PATIENT  HANDLING  POLICY  FOR HEALTH CARE FACILITIES IN NEW YORK STATE.
   16  WITHOUT SAFE PATIENT HANDLING LEGISLATION,  IT  IS  PREDICTED  THAT  THE
   17  DEMAND  FOR  NURSING  SERVICES  WILL  EXCEED THE SUPPLY BY NEARLY THIRTY
   18  PERCENT BY THE YEAR TWO THOUSAND TWENTY THUS DECREASING THE  QUALITY  OF
   19  HEALTH  CARE  IN  NEW  YORK STATE.   THERE ARE MANY BENEFITS THAT CAN BE
   20  DERIVED FROM SAFE PATIENT HANDLING PROGRAMS.   PATIENTS BENEFIT  THROUGH
   21  IMPROVED  QUALITY  OF  CARE  AND QUALITY OF LIFE BY REDUCING THE RISK OF
   22  FALLS, BEING DROPPED, FRICTION BURNS, SKIN TEARS AND BRUISES. CAREGIVERS
   23  BENEFIT FROM THE REDUCED RISK OF CAREER ENDING AND DEBILITATING INJURIES
   24  LEADING TO INCREASED MORALE, IMPROVED JOB SATISFACTION AND LONGEVITY  IN

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD04321-01-1

       A. 1370                             2

    1  THE  PROFESSION.  HEALTH CARE FACILITIES REALIZE A QUICK RETURN ON THEIR
    2  INVESTMENT THROUGH REDUCED WORKERS' COMPENSATION MEDICAL  AND  INDEMNITY
    3  COSTS,  REDUCED  LOST WORKDAYS AND IMPROVED RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION OF
    4  CAREGIVERS.  ALL  OF THIS WILL LEAD TO FISCAL IMPROVEMENT IN HEALTH CARE
    5  IN NEW YORK STATE.
    6    S 2999-H. DEFINITIONS. FOR THE PURPOSES OF THIS TITLE:
    7    1. "HEALTH CARE FACILITY"  SHALL  MEAN  ANY  INDIVIDUAL,  PARTNERSHIP,
    8  ASSOCIATION,  CORPORATION,  LIMITED  LIABILITY  COMPANY OR ANY PERSON OR
    9  GROUP OF PERSONS ACTING DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY ON BEHALF OF  OR  IN  THE
   10  INTEREST  OF  THE  EMPLOYER,  WHICH  PROVIDES  HEALTH CARE SERVICES IN A
   11  FACILITY LICENSED OR OPERATED PURSUANT TO ARTICLE TWENTY-EIGHT,  TWENTY-
   12  EIGHT-A  OR  THIRTY-SIX  OF THIS CHAPTER, OR THE MENTAL HYGIENE LAW, THE
   13  EDUCATION LAW OR THE CORRECTION LAW, INCLUDING ANY FACILITY OPERATED  BY
   14  THE  STATE,  A  POLITICAL SUBDIVISION OR A PUBLIC BENEFIT CORPORATION AS
   15  DEFINED BY SECTION SIXTY-SIX OF THE GENERAL CONSTRUCTION LAW.
   16    2. "NURSE" SHALL MEAN A REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL NURSE  OR  A  LICENSED
   17  PRACTICAL  NURSE  AS  DEFINED  BY ARTICLE ONE HUNDRED THIRTY-NINE OF THE
   18  EDUCATION LAW.
   19    3. "DIRECT CARE WORKER" SHALL MEAN  ANY  EMPLOYEE  OF  A  HEALTH  CARE
   20  FACILITY  THAT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR PATIENT HANDLING OR PATIENT ASSESSMENT
   21  AS A REGULAR OR INCIDENTAL  PART  OF  THEIR  EMPLOYMENT,  INCLUDING  ANY
   22  LICENSED OR UNLICENSED HEALTH CARE WORKER.
   23    4.  "EMPLOYEE  REPRESENTATIVE"  SHALL MEAN THE RECOGNIZED OR CERTIFIED
   24  COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGENT FOR NURSES  OR  DIRECT  CARE  WORKERS  OF  A
   25  HEALTH CARE FACILITY.
   26    5. "SAFE PATIENT HANDLING" SHALL MEAN THE USE OF ENGINEERING CONTROLS,
   27  LIFTING  AND  TRANSFER  AIDS,  OR ASSISTIVE DEVICES, BY NURSES OR DIRECT
   28  CARE WORKERS, INSTEAD OF MANUAL LIFTING TO PERFORM THE ACTS OF  LIFTING,
   29  TRANSFERRING AND REPOSITIONING OF HEALTH CARE PATIENTS AND RESIDENTS.
   30    6. "SAFE PATIENT HANDLING PROGRAM" SHALL INCLUDE:
   31    (A) A WRITTEN POLICY STATEMENT; AND
   32    (B) MANAGEMENT COMMITMENT AND EMPLOYEE INVOLVEMENT; AND
   33    (C) COMMITTEES; AND
   34    (D) RISK ASSESSMENTS; AND
   35    (E) INCIDENT INVESTIGATION; AND
   36    (F)  PROCUREMENT OF ENGINEERING CONTROLS, LIFTING AND TRANSFER AIDS OR
   37  ASSISTIVE DEVICES TO ENSURE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING; AND
   38    (G) EMPLOYEE TRAINING AND EDUCATION ON SAFE PATIENT HANDLING; AND
   39    (H) PROGRAM EVALUATION AND MODIFICATION.
   40    S 2999-I. NEW YORK STATE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING TASK FORCE.  1.  A  NEW
   41  YORK STATE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING TASK FORCE IS HEREBY CREATED WITHIN THE
   42  DEPARTMENT.   SUCH TASK FORCE SHALL CONSIST OF A TOTAL OF ELEVEN MEMBERS
   43  AND SHALL INCLUDE THE COMMISSIONER OR HIS OR HER DESIGNEE;  THE  COMMIS-
   44  SIONER  OF  LABOR OR HIS OR HER DESIGNEE; THREE MEMBERS APPOINTED BY THE
   45  GOVERNOR, TWO SUCH MEMBERS  SHALL  BE  REPRESENTATIVES  OF  HEALTH  CARE
   46  ORGANIZATIONS,  ONE  SUCH  MEMBER SHALL BE FROM AN EMPLOYEE ORGANIZATION
   47  REPRESENTING NURSES AND ONE SUCH MEMBER SHALL BE FROM AN EMPLOYEE ORGAN-
   48  IZATION REPRESENTING DIRECT CARE WORKERS;  TWO  SUCH  MEMBERS  SHALL  BE
   49  CERTIFIED ERGONOMIST EVALUATION SPECIALISTS; TWO MEMBERS TO BE APPOINTED
   50  BY  THE  TEMPORARY  PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE, WHO SHALL HAVE EXPERTISE IN
   51  FIELDS OF DISCIPLINE RELATED TO HEALTH CARE OR OCCUPATIONAL  SAFETY  AND
   52  ONE  SUCH  APPOINTEE SHALL BE FROM AN ORGANIZATION REPRESENTING EITHER A
   53  NURSE OR DIRECT CARE WORKER; TWO MEMBERS TO BE APPOINTED BY THE  SPEAKER
   54  OF  THE  ASSEMBLY,  WHO  SHALL  HAVE  EXPERTISE  IN FIELDS OF DISCIPLINE
   55  RELATED TO HEALTH CARE OR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY  AND  ONE  SUCH  APPOINTEE
   56  SHALL BE FROM AN ORGANIZATION REPRESENTING EITHER A NURSE OR DIRECT CARE

       A. 1370                             3

    1  WORKER; ONE MEMBER TO BE APPOINTED BY THE MINORITY LEADER OF THE SENATE,
    2  WHO  SHALL HAVE EXPERTISE IN FIELDS OF DISCIPLINE RELATED TO HEALTH CARE
    3  OR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY; AND ONE MEMBER APPOINTED BY THE MINORITY  LEADER
    4  OF  THE  ASSEMBLY,  WHO  SHALL  HAVE  EXPERTISE  IN FIELDS OF DISCIPLINE
    5  RELATED TO HEALTH CARE OR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY.
    6    2.  TASK  FORCE  MEMBERS  SHALL  RECEIVE  NO  COMPENSATION  FOR  THEIR
    7  SERVICES,  BUT  SHALL  BE  REIMBURSED  FOR ACTUAL AND NECESSARY EXPENSES
    8  INCURRED IN THE PERFORMANCE OF THEIR DUTIES.
    9    3. THE TASK FORCE SHALL BE APPOINTED NO LATER  THAN  JULY  FIRST,  TWO
   10  THOUSAND  THIRTEEN AND SHALL SERVE FOR A PERIOD OF TWO YEARS; ANY VACAN-
   11  CIES ON THE TASK FORCE SHALL BE FILLED IN THE MANNER PROVIDED FOR IN THE
   12  INITIAL APPOINTMENT.
   13    4. THE CHAIRPERSON OF THE TASK FORCE SHALL BE THE COMMISSIONER OR  HIS
   14  OR HER DESIGNEE.
   15    5. THE TASK FORCE SHALL MEET NO LESS THAN THREE TIMES A YEAR.
   16    6.  NOTWITHSTANDING  ANY  OTHER  PROVISION  OF  LAW, A MAJORITY OF THE
   17  MEMBERS OF THE TASK FORCE THEN IN OFFICE SHALL CONSTITUTE A  QUORUM  FOR
   18  THE  TRANSACTION OF BUSINESS OR THE EXERCISE OF POWER OR FUNCTION OF THE
   19  TASK FORCE. AN ACT, DETERMINATION OR DECISION OF  THE  MAJORITY  OF  THE
   20  MEMBERS  OF THE TASK FORCE SHALL BE HELD TO BE THE ACT, DETERMINATION OR
   21  DECISION OF THE TASK FORCE.
   22    7. THE TASK FORCE SHALL:
   23    (A) PREPARE A POLICY STATEMENT REQUIRING A COMPREHENSIVE SAFE  PATIENT
   24  HANDLING  PROGRAM  TO  BE  IMPLEMENTED AT ALL HEALTH CARE FACILITIES, AS
   25  DEFINED IN SUBDIVISION ONE OF SECTION TWENTY-NINE HUNDRED  NINETY-NINE-H
   26  OF  THIS TITLE.  THE POLICY STATEMENT SHALL INCLUDE THE REQUIREMENTS FOR
   27  DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING AN EFFECTIVE SAFE PATIENT  HANDLING  PROGRAM
   28  THAT  SHALL INCLUDE ALL ELEMENTS SPECIFIED IN SUBDIVISION SIX OF SECTION
   29  TWENTY-NINE HUNDRED NINETY-NINE-H OF THIS TITLE;
   30    (B) REVIEW  EXISTING  SAFE  PATIENT  HANDLING  PROGRAMS  OR  POLICIES,
   31  INCLUDING  DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS PREVIOUSLY AUTHORIZED BY CHAPTER SEVEN
   32  HUNDRED THIRTY-EIGHT OF THE LAWS OF TWO THOUSAND FIVE;
   33    (C) CONSULT WITH  ANY  ORGANIZATION,  EDUCATIONAL  INSTITUTION,  OTHER
   34  GOVERNMENT ENTITY OR AGENCY OR PERSON;
   35    (D) CONDUCT PUBLIC HEARINGS, AS IT DEEMS NECESSARY;
   36    (E)  IDENTIFY OR DEVELOP TRAINING MATERIALS AND PROCEDURES WITH REGARD
   37  TO THE EQUIPMENT OR TECHNOLOGY REQUIRED BY THE STATEWIDE POLICY;
   38    (F) REVIEW RULES AND REGULATIONS PRIOR TO ADOPTION BY THE DEPARTMENT;
   39    (G) REVIEW AND UPDATE THE POLICY STATEMENT ON A BI-ANNUAL BASIS; AND
   40    (H) SUBMIT A REPORT TO THE COMMISSIONER BY JULY  FIRST,  TWO  THOUSAND
   41  FOURTEEN  IDENTIFYING  SAFE PATIENT HANDLING PROGRAM ELEMENTS AND RECOM-
   42  MENDATIONS OF SAFE PATIENT LIFTING EQUIPMENT, TECHNIQUES OR DEVICES.
   43    8. ALL STATE DEPARTMENTS, COMMISSIONS, AGENCIES AND PUBLIC AUTHORITIES
   44  SHALL PROVIDE THE TASK FORCE WITH ANY REASONABLY REQUESTED ASSISTANCE OF
   45  ADVICE IN A TIMELY MANNER.
   46    S 2999-J. STATEWIDE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY. 1. THE COMMISSIONER,
   47  IN CONSULTATION WITH THE TASK FORCE, SHALL PROMULGATE  RULES  AND  REGU-
   48  LATIONS  FOR  A  STATEWIDE  SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY FOR HEALTH CARE
   49  FACILITIES COVERED BY THIS TITLE. SUCH POLICY SHALL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO
   50  ALL FACILITIES COVERED BY THIS TITLE ON OR  BEFORE  JANUARY  FIRST,  TWO
   51  THOUSAND FIFTEEN.
   52    2.  THE STATEWIDE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY SHALL INCLUDE STANDARDS
   53  WITH REGARD TO:
   54    (A) THE EQUIPMENT, DEVICES OR TECHNOLOGY TO BE  USED  BY  A  NURSE  OR
   55  DIRECT CARE WORKER WHO IS ENGAGED IN PATIENT HANDLING;

       A. 1370                             4

    1    (B)  THE  RATIO OF SUCH EQUIPMENT OR TECHNOLOGY BASED UPON THE TYPE OF
    2  FACILITY, THE NUMBER OF BEDS IN A FACILITY, THE NUMBER  OF  PATIENT-HAN-
    3  DLING  TASKS, TYPES OF CARE UNITS, PATIENT POPULATIONS, AND PATIENT CARE
    4  AREAS;
    5    (C)  THE  MINIMUM  NUMBER  OF  DEVICES TO ENSURE THAT CURRENT ASSESSED
    6  HAZARDS ARE ELIMINATED OR MITIGATED;
    7    (D) ESTABLISHING  PROCEDURES  FOR  THE  SUBMISSION  AND  REPORTING  OF
    8  COMPLIANCE BY EACH HEALTH CARE FACILITY COVERED BY THIS TITLE; AND
    9    (E)  ESTABLISHING  PROCEDURES  FOR COMPLAINTS OR VIOLATIONS, INCLUDING
   10  THE FILING PROCESS, REVIEW, AND EVALUATION AND CORRECTIVE ACTION OF SUCH
   11  COMPLAINTS.
   12    3. EACH HEALTH CARE FACILITY SHALL FILE WITH THE  DEPARTMENT  BY  JULY
   13  FIRST,  TWO  THOUSAND  THIRTEEN A DETAILED PLAN TO COMPLY WITH THE RULES
   14  AND REGULATIONS OF THE  STATEWIDE  SAFE  PATIENT  HANDLING  POLICY.  THE
   15  DEPARTMENT SHALL ACCEPT SUCH PLAN BY JULY FIRST, TWO THOUSAND SIXTEEN.
   16    S  2999-K.  HEALTH  CARE FACILITY SAFE PATIENT HANDLING COMMITTEES. 1.
   17  EACH HEALTH CARE  FACILITY  SHALL  ESTABLISH  A  SAFE  PATIENT  HANDLING
   18  COMMITTEE EITHER BY CREATING A NEW COMMITTEE OR ASSIGNING THE POWERS AND
   19  DUTIES  TO  AN EXISTING COMMITTEE.   AT LEAST ONE-HALF OF THE MEMBERS OF
   20  THE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING COMMITTEE SHALL  BE  FRONTLINE  NON-MANAGERIAL
   21  NURSES OR DIRECT CARE WORKERS. AT LEAST ONE NON-MANAGERIAL NURSE AND ONE
   22  NON-MANAGERIAL  DIRECT CARE WORKER SHALL BE ON THE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING
   23  COMMITTEE. THE COMMITTEE SHALL HAVE TWO CO-CHAIRS WITH ONE FROM  MANAGE-
   24  MENT AND ONE FRONTLINE NON-MANAGERIAL NURSE OR DIRECT CARE WORKER.
   25    2.  THE  SAFE  PATIENT  HANDLING COMMITTEE SHALL: (A) SET CRITERIA FOR
   26  EVALUATION OF PATIENTS AND/OR RESIDENTS TO DETERMINE WHICH  LIFT  AND/OR
   27  REPOSITIONING  EQUIPMENT,  DEVICES OR TECHNOLOGY ARE TO BE USED; AND FOR
   28  PERFORMANCE OF RISK  ASSESSMENTS  OF  THE  ENVIRONMENT,  JOB  TASKS  AND
   29  PATIENT NEEDS;
   30    (B)  ENSURE  LIFT  AND/OR  REPOSITIONING EQUIPMENT IS SET UP, USED AND
   31  MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO MANUFACTURER'S INSTRUCTIONS;
   32    (C) PROVIDE INITIAL AND ON-GOING YEARLY TRAINING AND EDUCATION ON SAFE
   33  PATIENT HANDLING FOR CURRENT EMPLOYEES AND NEW HIRES,  AND  ENSURE  THAT
   34  RETRAINING FOR THOSE FOUND TO BE DEFICIENT IS PROVIDED AS NEEDED WITHOUT
   35  IMPACT TO THE EMPLOYMENT STATUS OF THE RETRAINED EMPLOYEES;
   36    (D)  SET UP AND UTILIZE A PROCESS FOR INCIDENT INVESTIGATION AND POST-
   37  INVESTIGATION REVIEW WHICH INCLUDES A PLAN OF CORRECTION AND IMPLEMENTA-
   38  TION OF CONTROLS;
   39    (E) MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE ACQUISITION OF  EQUIPMENT  OR  PROCE-
   40  DURES BEYOND THE MINIMUM STATE RECOMMENDATIONS; AND
   41    (F) PERFORM, AT MINIMUM, AN ANNUAL PROGRAM ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION.
   42    S  2999-L. ENFORCEMENT. 1. ANY NURSE OR DIRECT CARE WORKER OR EMPLOYEE
   43  REPRESENTATIVE WHO BELIEVES THE HEALTH CARE FACILITY  HAS  NOT  MET  THE
   44  STANDARDS  SET  FORTH IN THIS TITLE SHALL BRING THE MATTER TO THE ATTEN-
   45  TION OF THE HEALTH CARE FACILITY IN THE FORM OF  A  WRITTEN  NOTICE  AND
   46  SHALL  AFFORD  THE  HEALTH  CARE  FACILITY  A  REASONABLE OPPORTUNITY TO
   47  CORRECT SUCH  DEFICIENCIES,  PROVIDED  THAT  SUCH  NOTICE  NEED  NOT  BE
   48  PROVIDED  WHERE  THE  NURSE  OR DIRECT WORKER OR EMPLOYEE REPRESENTATIVE
   49  REASONABLY BELIEVES THAT THE FAILURE TO MEET STANDARDS PRESENTS AN IMMI-
   50  NENT THREAT TO THE SAFETY OF A SPECIFIC NURSE OR DIRECT CARE WORKER,  OR
   51  TO  THE  GENERAL  HEALTH  OF  A SPECIFIC PATIENT, AND REPORTING WILL NOT
   52  RESULT IN CORRECTIVE ACTION.
   53    2. IN THE EVENT THAT THE HEALTH CARE FACILITY RECEIVING NOTICE  PURSU-
   54  ANT  TO  SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION DOES NOT TAKE CORRECTIVE ACTION
   55  WITHIN SIXTY DAYS, OR IN THE EVENT THAT NOTICE  OF  A  FAILURE  TO  MEET
   56  STANDARDS IS NOT REQUIRED PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION, A

       A. 1370                             5

    1  NURSE  OR DIRECT CARE WORKER SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT TO REFUSE TO ENGAGE IN
    2  PATIENT HANDLING UNTIL THE HEALTH CARE FACILITY HAS ADEQUATELY ADDRESSED
    3  THE SPECIFIC FAILURE TO MEET STANDARDS.   UPON REFUSAL,  SUCH  NURSE  OR
    4  DIRECT  CARE  WORKER OR HIS OR HER REPRESENTATIVE SHALL FILE A COMPLAINT
    5  TO THE DEPARTMENT IN THE MANNER SET FORTH IN THE STATEWIDE SAFE  PATIENT
    6  HANDLING POLICY.
    7    3.  NO  EMPLOYER  SHALL  TAKE  RETALIATORY ACTION AGAINST ANY NURSE OR
    8  DIRECT CARE WORKER FOR RAISING CONCERNS OR ISSUES REGARDING SAFE PATIENT
    9  HANDLING, FILING A COMPLAINT OR REFUSING TO ENGAGE IN PATIENT HANDLING.
   10    4. NURSES AND DIRECT CARE WORKERS, AS DEFINED IN  SECTION  TWENTY-NINE
   11  HUNDRED  NINETY-NINE-H  OF  THIS TITLE SHALL BE CONSIDERED EMPLOYEES FOR
   12  THE PURPOSES OF SECTION SEVEN HUNDRED FORTY-ONE OF THE LABOR LAW.
   13    5. THE DEPARTMENT AND THE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR SHALL PUBLISH  AND  MAKE
   14  PUBLIC WHICH HEALTH CARE FACILITIES ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE STATEWIDE
   15  SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY.
   16    S  3.  The  education law is amended by adding a new section 6510-f to
   17  read as follows:
   18    S 6510-F. STATE SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY.   1. THE  REFUSAL  OF  A
   19  LICENSED  PRACTICAL  NURSE  OR  A  REGISTERED NURSE TO ENGAGE IN PATIENT
   20  HANDLING SHALL NOT CONSTITUTE PATIENT ABANDONMENT  OR  NEGLECT  IF  SUCH
   21  NURSE  HAS,  IN  A  MANNER  CONSISTENT WITH ARTICLE TWENTY-NINE-D OF THE
   22  PUBLIC HEALTH LAW AND THE RULES AND REGULATIONS PROMULGATED PURSUANT  TO
   23  SUCH  ARTICLE,  REFUSED  A  PATIENT  HANDLING  ASSIGNMENT  AND  FILED  A
   24  COMPLAINT WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH.
   25    2. THE REFUSAL OF A LICENSED  OR  UNLICENSED  HEALTH  CARE  WORKER  TO
   26  ENGAGE  IN  PATIENT  HANDLING NOT CONSISTENT WITH THE STATE SAFE PATIENT
   27  HANDLING POLICY OR A FACILITY'S SAFE PATIENT HANDLING POLICY  SHALL  NOT
   28  BE  CONSIDERED  PROFESSIONAL  MISCONDUCT.  THE  REFUSAL OF A LICENSED OR
   29  UNLICENSED HEALTH CARE WORKER TO ENGAGE IN PATIENT  HANDLING  SHALL  NOT
   30  CONSTITUTE  PATIENT  ABANDONMENT  OR  NEGLECT  IF  SUCH WORKER HAS, IN A
   31  MANNER CONSISTENT WITH ARTICLE TWENTY-NINE-D OF THE  PUBLIC  HEALTH  LAW
   32  AND  THE  RULES  AND  REGULATIONS  PROMULGATED PURSUANT TO SUCH ARTICLE,
   33  REFUSED A PATIENT HANDLING ASSIGNMENT AND FILED  A  COMPLAINT  WITH  THE
   34  DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH.
   35    S 4. This act shall take effect on the one hundred twentieth day after
   36  it shall have become a law.
actClause: AN ACT to amend the public health law and the education law, in relation to a safe patient handling policy for health care facilities
